reg:regulation.reg:title:
Provincial Court (Child, Family and
Community Service Act) Rules
reg:regulation.reg:amsincluded: [Last amended December 19, 2022 by B.C. Reg. 216/2022 as amended by B.C. Reg. 270/2022]

bcl:section.bcl:text: The purpose of these rules is to promote the safety and well-being of children by allowing court decisions to be obtained fairly and efficiently, in matters arising under the Child, Family and Community Service Act.

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Child, Family and Community Service Act;
business day means a Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday that is not a holiday;
clerk means a member of the registry staff;
court means the Provincial Court except where the Act or these rules provide otherwise;
lawyer of record, in relation to a party, means a lawyer who has provided notification or advised the court in accordance with Rule 8 (20);
method of attendance, in relation to a case conference, mini-hearing and hearing, includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: attending in person, and
attending by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: party, with respect to a proceeding under the Act, means a person who, under the Act, is a party to that proceeding;
registry means a registry of the court.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In these rules, other words and expressions have the meaning given to them in the Act, unless the context indicates otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To initiate a presentation hearing, a director must complete and file with the court a Presentation Form (Form 1).
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 351/2005, s. 2 (a).]

To apply for an order, other than an order made at a presentation hearing, a person must complete and file with the court an Application for an Order (Form 2) or an Application to Change Method of Attendance (Form 10.5), as applicable, unless a judge permits otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Applications to change or cancel an order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order changing or cancelling another order, a person must complete and file with the court an Application to Change or Cancel an Order (Form 3), unless a judge permits otherwise.
At a hearing or a case conference, a judge may permit an application to be made orally in court, without the filing of a form.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Where a presentation hearing must be initiated
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A Presentation Form must be filed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the registry closest to the child's habitual residence, or
in the registry closest to where the child was removed or taken into care

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: unless a judge permits otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Where an application must be filed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application in Form 2, Form 3 or Form 10.5 must be filed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the registry where the file is located, unless Rule 8 (12) or (13) applies, or
if there is no file, then as required by subrule (5), as if the application were a Presentation Form.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may conduct a hearing or part of a hearing with one or more persons attending by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Some applications may be granted without a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may make the following orders without a hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order under Rule 6 (10), permitting the use of another service method;
an order under Rule 8 (2), shortening or extending a time period;
an order under Rule 9 (4), changing the method of attendance unless the order is in relation to a hearing at which sworn oral evidence is given;
a consent order or an order dispensing with consent, under section 60 of the Act;
an order under section 69 of the Act, shortening or extending the time for serving notice or dispensing with notice.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for an order without a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order to be made under subrule (8) (a), (b), (c) or (d), a person must file

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an affidavit setting out the facts on which the application is based, and
the application form. (See Rule 1 (2) and (3))

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for an order for changing method of attendance without a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order under subrule (8) (b.1), a person must file the application form (Form 10.5). (See Rule 9 (5))
A person may, until January 17, 2023,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete and file with the court a Presentation Form using Form 1 as it read on December 18, 2022,
complete and file with the court an Application for an Order using Form 2 as it read on December 18, 2022, and
complete and file with the court an Application to Change or Cancel an Order using Form 3 as it read on December 18, 2022.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 216/2022, s. 3 (a).]
A judge may at any time direct the parties and their lawyers to attend a case conference

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a party requests it, or
if the judge considers that it may promote a fair and efficient resolution of the issues.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: When a case conference is directed, the judge must review the extent of disclosure made and requested under section 64 of the Act and may make any order for disclosure consistent with the Act.

When a case conference is directed, the director must notify the other parties of the date, time and place of the conference, unless the conference was directed when the parties or their lawyers of record were present.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What happens at a case conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At a case conference, a judge may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: facilitate the resolution of any issues in dispute;
mediate any issues in dispute, other than the issue of whether the child needs protection;
with the consent of the parties, refer any issue, other than the issue of whether a child needs protection, to mediation or other alternative dispute resolution mechanism under section 22 of the Act;
decide any issues that do not require evidence or that can be decided on the basis of facts agreed to by the parties;
make any order in the terms the parties agree to, subject to section 60 of the Act;
review the adequacy of disclosure by the parties, including responses to requests for disclosure under section 64 of the Act;
order that a party provide to another party, within a set time, a summary of the intended evidence of a potential witness;
order a party to allow another party to inspect and copy specific documents or records to the extent permitted by the Act;
order that those applications that cannot be made at the case conference be brought within a set time;
order that a statement of agreed facts be filed within a set time;
give directions about any evidence that will be required, how it will be received and the procedure that will be followed, if a hearing is necessary or a mini-hearing is directed;
order a party to produce anything as evidence at a hearing;
direct that any further case conference be held before the same judge;
with the consent of the parties, direct the parties to attend a mini-hearing if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the matter can be resolved on the basis of limited evidence and submissions, and
a mini-hearing can be held earlier than the matter could be set for a full hearing;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without hearing witnesses, give a non-binding opinion on the probable outcome of a hearing;
set a date for a hearing or mini-hearing;
make an order about the method of attendance of a person at a further case conference;
make any other order or give any direction for the fair and efficient resolution of the issues.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge directs the parties to attend a mini-hearing, the court must notify them of the date, time and place, unless the date was set when the parties or their lawyers of record were present.
At a mini-hearing, the parties will attend before a judge who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hear submissions and evidence as directed at the case conference, and
make any order that could be made after a full hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The following persons may attend case conferences:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the parties and their lawyers;
any other person the judge allows.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Direction where case conference to be conducted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The chief judge may direct that case conferences set at one place be conducted at another place.
To require a witness to attend court, a party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a subpoena (Form 4), and
serve a copy of the subpoena on the witness personally at least 7 days before the date the witness is required to appear. (See Rule 8 (2))

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At the time the subpoena is served, the party subpoenaing the witness must offer the witness

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reasonable estimated travelling expenses for a subpoena to appear in person, or
for a subpoena to appear by another method of attendance, the reasonable estimated cost of the telephone call, video conference or other method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to change a witness's method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A witness may apply to a judge under Rule 9 (5) to change a witness's method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may change a witness's method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The judge may order a witness to attend court by any method of attendance that the judge considers appropriate in the circumstances.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a witness served with a subpoena must do
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a subpoena must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: appear in court on the date and at the time and place stated on the subpoena, and
if the witness attends court in person, bring to court any records and other things required by the subpoena.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Subpoena may be cancelled or varied
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a subpoena may apply under Rule 1 (2) to a judge, who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cancel the subpoena if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person is not needed as a witness,
it would be a hardship for the person to appear in court as required by the subpoena, or
in the case of a child witness, the judge considers that it would not be in the child's best interests to require the child to testify, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: vary the subpoena to allow the witness to attend court by another method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a witness does not obey a subpoena
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may issue a warrant (Form 5) for the arrest of a witness who does not appear in court as required by a subpoena if the judge is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the subpoena was served on the witness,
reasonable travelling expenses were offered to the witness, and
justice requires the presence of the witness.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a judge changes a witness's method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge changes a witness's method of attendance, the judge

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must direct the witness

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: how, and by what date, to submit and serve any records and other things, if the witness will not be attending in person, and
where or how to attend, including by providing a telephone number or video conferencing information, if applicable, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may order

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the return of any money that was provided under subrule (2), or
that the party subpoenaing the witness pay for the witness's travelling expenses, telephone call, video conference or other reasonable estimated cost of the method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How long a warrant for arrest of witness is in force
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A warrant remains in force until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the witness named in the warrant appears in court either voluntarily or under the warrant, or
a judge cancels the warrant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A witness who is arrested under a warrant must be brought before a judge or justice of the peace as soon as practicable.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the judge may do when the witness appears
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the witness's evidence is still required, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: release the witness on giving the witness a release (Form 6) requiring the witness to appear in court on the date and at the time and place stated in the release, or
order a sheriff or peace officer to detain the witness in custody until the presence of the witness is no longer required.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may make the release of a witness under subrule (8) (a) subject to any conditions respecting reporting or residency or entering into a recognizance that the judge considers necessary to make sure the witness attends.
At a hearing, evidence may be given orally on oath or affirmation or, if the judge allows,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by affidavit, subject to Rule 5,
by statements of facts agreed to by the parties, or
as permitted under section 68 (2) (b) of the Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person who is served with an application does not appear in court on the date and at the time and place set for the hearing, the judge may hear the application and make the order applied for if the judge thinks it is fair to do so in the absence of that person.

Subrule (2) applies also if a designated representative of a First Nation, an Indigenous community, a Treaty First Nation or the Nisg̱a'a Lisims Government is served with an application and a designated representative of the First Nation, Indigenous community, Treaty First Nation or Nisg̱a'a Lisims Government does not appear in court on the date and at the time and place set for the hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Advance notice of experts' evidence required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may call an expert to give evidence of the expert's opinion only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party provides a written summary of the expert's evidence to all other parties at least 30 days before the expert is called to give evidence, or
a judge grants permission.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Experts' reports must be given in advance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Instead of calling an expert to give evidence, a party may introduce a report stating opinions of an expert, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party provides a copy of the report to all other parties at least 30 days before the report is introduced, or
a judge grants permission.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A director, or a delegate of a director, is not an expert for the purposes of notice under subrule (4) or (5).
A statement of qualifications in an expert's report is proof that the expert has those qualifications unless there is evidence to the contrary.
A report stating the opinions of an expert may be introduced without proof of the expert's signature.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Experts may be called for cross-examination
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party receiving another party's expert report may serve on the other party, at least 14 days before the hearing date, a notice requiring the expert to attend the hearing for cross-examination. (See Rule 8 (2))

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cost of calling other party's expert
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge determines that calling another party's expert was unnecessary, the judge may order the party who required the expert to attend to pay the expert's expenses.
Where an affidavit is permitted under these rules, it must be in Form 7.
Any exhibits referred to in an affidavit must be identified and attached to the affidavit.
With the permission of the judge, an affidavit may be used in evidence even though it does not comply in form with this Rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Affidavit must be filed and served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Evidence may be given by affidavit at a hearing only if, at least 2 days before the date of the hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: copies of the affidavit are filed in the registry, and
a copy of the affidavit is served on every person who is entitled to notice of the hearing. (See Rule 8 (2))

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An address for service may be any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a mailing address;
an email address;
a facsimile number.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the Act or these rules provide otherwise, an application must be served at least 2 days before the date set for the hearing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the other parties, and
if an order is sought against some other person, on that person. (See Rule 8 (2))

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A copy of an application or other document served need not be a filed copy.
Service of an application is not required if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application is for permission to use another service method,
the application is for access to a child under section 17 (1) of the Act,
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 49/2019, s. 3 (a).]
the application is for a consent order under section 60 of the Act and each of the required consents has been obtained or dispensed with, or
a judge so orders.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Documents required by the Act or these rules to be served may be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on an individual

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the individual,

if the individual is a party, by registered mail or by email to the last address for service given under subrule (5), (6) or (7), or by facsimile transmission to the last facsimile number given as an address for service under subrule (5), (6) or (7), or
if the individual is a party with a lawyer of record, by leaving a copy at that lawyer's office or by emailing or by sending a facsimile transmission to that lawyer's office;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a designated representative of a First Nation, an Indigenous community, a Treaty First Nation or the Nisg̱a'a Lisims Government by emailing to the email address, or by sending a facsimile transmission to the facsimile number for service provided by the First Nation, Indigenous community, Treaty First Nation or Nisg̱a'a Lisims Government or by leaving a copy with the designated representative;
on a society within the meaning of the Societies Act

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by registered mail to the mailing address of the society's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies,
by leaving a copy at the delivery address of the society's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies or with a director or officer of the society, or
by emailing to the email address of the society, if the society has provided an email address as an address for service;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by registered mail to the mailing address of the company's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies,

by leaving a copy of it at the delivery address of the company's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies or with a director or officer of the company, or with a receptionist or a person at the company's place of business who appears to manage the company's business there, or
by emailing to the email address of the company, if the company provided an email address as an address for service;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on an unincorporated association

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by registered mail to the registered office of the association,
by leaving a copy with an officer of the association, or
by emailing to the email address of the association, if the association provided an email address as an address for service;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a director

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with or by sending a facsimile transmission to the director's lawyer of record,
by emailing to the director or to the director's lawyer of record, or
by leaving a copy at, or by sending a facsimile transmission to, the district office with conduct of the case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party must give an address for service either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the face of a document filed by the party, or
by filing a notice of address for service (Form 8).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person entitled to notice under section 38 (1) (b) to (e) of the Act may file a notice of address for service (Form 8).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Party must notify of change of address
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party's address for service changes, the party must promptly notify the other parties of the new address either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the face of a document filed by the party, or
by filing a new notice of address for service (Form 8).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any document may be served on a child who is 12 years of age or older by leaving a copy of it with the child, unless a judge orders otherwise.
A document may be served on a child who is under 12 years of age, but only if a judge so orders.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Permission to use other service methods
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document cannot be served as provided in these rules or if the person to be served is temporarily outside the Province, a person may apply to a judge who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permit another method of service to be used, and
direct how service is to be proved.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Service of a document may be proved by filing the following at the registry:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for personal service of a document, a certificate of service (Form 9);
for service by registered mail, a certificate of service (Form 9) that includes one of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy, produced by facsimile or otherwise, of the signature obtained by Canada Post at the time the document was delivered;
a printout of the delivery confirmation made available on the internet by Canada Post;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for personal service on the lawyer of record, a copy of the document signed by the lawyer of record or an articled student or by a partner or employee of the firm;
for service by facsimile transmission, a certificate of service (Form 9) with a transmission report generated by the sending machine;
for service by email, a certificate of service (Form 9) with the following attached to the certificate:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a printout of the first page of the email message that includes the sender's name, the recipient's email address, the date the email was sent and the time the email was sent;
if the printout of the first page of the email message does not list the name of the document as an attachment to the email, a copy of the document.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When service by email is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document transmitted for service by email under this rule is deemed to be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is transmitted before 4 p.m. on a business day, the document is deemed to be served on the day of transmission;
if the document is transmitted on a day that is not a business day, or after 4 p.m. on a business day, the document is deemed to be served on the next business day.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If document does not reach a person
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document was served in accordance with subrule (4), a person may show on application that the document

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: did not come to the person's notice,
came to the person's notice later than when it was served or effectively served, or
was incomplete or illegible, and

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the judge may make orders or give directions to serve the document in a specified manner or give any other order or direction that the judge considers appropriate.
A person may, until January 17, 2023, file with the registry a certificate of service using Form 9 as it read on December 18, 2022.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may require copy of served document
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may require that a copy of the served document be attached to the certificate of service (Form 9).
Instead of requiring proof of service under subrule (11), a judge or registrar may allow a person to prove by sworn oral evidence that the person has personally served a document.
An order takes effect on the day it was made by a judge unless the judge orders otherwise.
The director's lawyer of record prepares the order as soon as practicable, unless the judge orders otherwise.
Orders must be prepared in Form 10, or, in the case of a protective intervention order under section 28 of the Act or a restraining order under section 98 of the Act, in Form 10.1.
An order must be signed as approved by the lawyer of record for each party who was represented, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the judge orders otherwise, or
the order is a protective intervention order made under section 28 of the Act or a restraining order made under section 98 of the Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may apply to a judge to settle the terms of an order when there is a dispute about the terms. (See Rule 1 (2))

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Delivering the order to the registry
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After an order is signed as approved in accordance with subrule (4), it must be delivered to the registry to be signed by a judge, filed with the court and date stamped with the registry stamp.
After an order is signed by the judge and filed with the court, a clerk must provide a copy

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to the lawyer of record for each party who was represented, and
to every other party on request

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: unless the judge orders otherwise.
Any judge may correct, at any time, a clerical mistake in an order or a mistake arising from an accidental slip or omission.
Whether or not the parties consent, a judge may adjourn a hearing to a specific date.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may shorten or extend time limits
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may shorten a period of time for doing anything required under these rules or may extend the period even though it has expired.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 533/95, Rule 8 (5).]
A hearing may be adjourned only

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the permission of a judge, or

in the case of a hearing at which sworn oral evidence will not be given, if the director's lawyer of record files with the court a Consent Adjournment form (Form 10.2) after having obtained consent of all of the parties or their lawyer of record, as applicable.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 216/2022, s. 19 (b).]
A judge may change or cancel an order made in the absence of a party who received notice of a hearing if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that party applies within a reasonable time,
the party had a good reason for failing to attend when the order was made,
there is a good reason for changing or cancelling the order, and
the change or cancellation would be in the best interests of the child.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At any time during a hearing, a judge may order that a person, whether or not a party, be given notice of the hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Powers that any judge may exercise
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any judge may do any of the following without being seized of a matter:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receive the reports and information presented to the court at a presentation hearing;
adjourn a hearing before evidence is heard;
make orders or give directions on procedural matters;
hold a case conference or mini-hearing under Rule 2;
make orders about a person's method of attendance at a case conference, mini-hearing or hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge who starts a hearing must continue
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (8), a judge who has heard any evidence at a hearing must finish the hearing unless the judge dies or is otherwise unable to act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If judge cannot finish the hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge who has begun to hear evidence dies or is otherwise unable to act, another judge will hear the case and that judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: start the hearing again and re-hear all the evidence, or
with the consent of the parties, continue with the hearing where it left off, giving directions for hearing evidence as the judge considers necessary.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may give a direction on any procedural matter that is not provided for in the Act or these rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may order transfer of file
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may order a file transferred to another registry, for the purposes of one application or for all purposes, after considering

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the balance of convenience,
any special circumstances that exist, and
the best interests of the child.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the parties agree, a clerk may transfer a file to another registry, for the purposes of one application or for all purposes, if the parties

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a written and signed consent to the transfer, and
file the consent in the registry where the file is located.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: With the judge's permission, a copy of a document may be used in court instead of the original.
Unless a judge orders otherwise, no person other than the following may search a registry file respecting a matter under the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party;
a party's lawyer of record;
a person authorized in writing by a party;
a person authorized in writing by a party's lawyer of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not comply with the rules
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party does not comply with these rules, the judge may after considering the principles at section 2 of the Act

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cancel a step taken or an order made or disregard a document filed in the course of the application, or
make any order or give any direction that the judge thinks is fair, including an order dismissing the application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any document may be filed in a registry by facsimile transmission to that registry, but a judge may require that the original of a document be filed later.
The forms in Appendix A are prescribed for the purposes of these rules.
Forms generated by the user must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in substantial compliance with the prescribed forms, and
show the applicable words of the prescribed form in regular type and the words supplied by the user in boldface type.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of these rules,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a lawyer must provide notification to the other parties that the lawyer is the lawyer of record for a party by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: completing and filing with the court a Notice of Lawyer of Record for Party (Form 10.3), and
serving on each party the form referred to in subparagraph (i), or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a lawyer must advise the court, when appearing in court, that the lawyer is the lawyer of record for a party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Ceasing to be lawyer of record
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of these rules,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a lawyer must provide notification to the other parties that the lawyer is no longer the lawyer of record for a party by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: completing and filing with the court a Notice of Removal of Lawyer of Record for Party (Form 10.4), and
serving on each party the form referred to in subparagraph (i), or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a lawyer must advise the court, when appearing in court, that the lawyer is no longer the lawyer of record for a party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may waive or modify process in respect of notification of lawyer of record
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may, at any time, waive or modify the processes in subrules (20) and (21).
Case conferences, mini-hearings and hearings must be attended in person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Direction by chief judge for exception to default
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (1), the chief judge may direct that a class of case conferences, mini-hearings or hearings may or must be attended by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Classes of case conferences, mini-hearings and hearings
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A direction under subrule (2) may be different for different court locations, court registries, types of case conferences, mini-hearings or hearings or classes of persons or circumstances.
If the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chief judge gives a direction under subrule (2) that a case conference, mini-hearing or hearing may or must be attended by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication;
an application is granted under subrule (5) that a person may attend a case conference, mini-hearing or hearing by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication;
a person attends a hearing that is required under subrule (6) (a) or (b) by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication;
a designated representative attends a case conference, mini-hearing or hearing by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the court must direct the persons attending

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: how, and by what date, to submit and serve any records and other things, if the person will not be attending in person, and
where or how to attend, including by providing a telephone number or video conferencing information, if applicable.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to change method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrules (1) and (2), a person may apply to change the person's own or another person's method of attendance at a case conference, mini-hearing or hearing to the court under Rule 1 (2) by completing and filing with the court an Application to Change Method of Attendance (Form 10.5).
An application under subrule (5) does not require service or a hearing unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the judge requires notice and a hearing, in which case the judge may require service in accordance with Rule 6 or in any other manner the judge considers appropriate, or
the application is in respect of a court proceeding at which sworn oral evidence will be given, in which case the judge may require service in accordance with Rule 6.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Hearing on application to change method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless a judge orders otherwise, a person may attend a hearing that is required under subrule (6) (a) or (b) by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication.
A designated representative of a First Nation, an Indigenous community, a Treaty First Nation or the Nisg̱a'a Lisims Government

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may, despite subrules (1) and (2), attend a case conference, mini-hearing or hearing by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication if the designated representative does not intend to give sworn oral evidence or to call another person to give sworn oral evidence, and
must attend a case conference, mini-hearing or hearing in person if the designated representative intends to give sworn oral evidence or to call another person to give sworn oral evidence unless

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a direction under subrule (2) applies to the designated representative, or
the designated representative makes a successful application under subrule (5).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrules (1) and (2), a judge who is conducting a case conference, mini-hearing or hearing at which persons are appearing by telephone, video case conference or other means of electronic communication may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjourn the conference, mini-hearing or hearing at any time, and

require persons to attend the case conference, mini-hearing or hearing, or any further case conferences, mini-hearings or hearings, in person or by another method of attendance that the judge considers appropriate in the circumstances.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of these rules, other than subrules (1) and (8) (b) of this Rule, a reference to attending, appearing, conducting, giving, being present, being in court or being at a place or location is not to be interpreted as requiring in-person attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Case conference, mini-hearing or hearing has an associated physical location
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a case conference, mini-hearing or hearing does not take place at a physical location because all persons attend the case conference, mini-hearing or hearing by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication, the case conference, mini-hearing or hearing is considered to take place at the court served by the registry where the court file is.

To all Peace Officers in British Columbia:

This Court orders you to arrest ...................................................................................................................... and bring that person before any Judge or Justice of the Peace as soon as practicable.
The reason for the arrest is that:
the person did not comply with an order under section 17 (2) (b) to disclose all the information known to the person that may assist the director in locating the child;
the person did not comply with an order under section 17 (2) (c) to allow the director or another person to interview or to visually examine the child, or to do both.
WARRANT TO ENTER DWELLING AND ARREST
To all Peace Officers in British Columbia:
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • immediately before the entry, you have reasonable grounds to believe that the person is present in the dwelling; and
• the person is brought before any Judge or Justice of the Peace as soon as practicable.
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: The reason for the arrest is that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the person has contravened or is contravening
a protective intervention order under section 28 of the Act, or
a restraining order under section 98 of the Act
and is or will be present in the dwelling.
